results.title: Changing horizons
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Eric Thompson
results.brief_description: Bushwalking in Australia means leaving the beaten tracks and venturing into the wild, rugged mountain country, with little more than the pursuit of adventure as the motive, and good healthy exercise and the companionship of fellow walkers, the rewards. The film includes scenes of Lamington National Park, Queensland, the upper reaches of the Yarra in Victoria’s Warburton Ranges, and the Blue Mountains in New South Wales.

results.title: Changing art in a changing world (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Through a wide range of visual experience this film shows that the entire world in which we live is in a constant state of change. For artists, change is enormously important. It compels them to study their subject carefully, to change and modify ideas so as to express themself in their art in the best possible way.

results.title: Changes, changes (K)
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel, Weston Woods Studios and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: Set to the music of an all-wood orchestra, this simple un narrated story portrays a pair of wooden dolls which magically come to life. Initially the blocks formed a house for the man and lady. They then change into a fire engine to put out a fire in the house and into a truck, train and ship to take the wooden couple on a holiday. Finally they form a house again. Adapted from the book of the same title by Pat Hutchins. Animation by Zdenka Skripkova. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: Changes in its surface
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Earth”.
Uses the illustration of an erupting volcano to show that the surface of the earth is changing. Explains and demonstrates other forces both internal and external that are changing the earth’s surface.

results.title: Changes
results.creator_credit: Kent Chadwick, Filmpartnership, Victorian Film Corporation and Karin Altmann
results.brief_description: The film aims to promote a greater understanding of the changes which are taking place in the workforce. It shows women working in non-traditional female occupations such as commercial photography, bank manager, plumber, jockey, explosives technician and stage manager, and attempts to encourage young women to consider a broader range of jobs than those commonly regarded as suitable for women. In 1979 women represented 36% of the workforce and 43% of all women were in paid employment but research showed that women tended to be concentrated in a narrower spectrum of occupations than men, thereby limiting their opportunities. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
